content: The Act titled "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" includes provisions for increased disclosure reports, reporting by national political party committees, electronic disclosure, public access to broadcasting records, and software for filing reports. It also addresses soft money of national political parties and contribution limits. The Act "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" includes provisions for disclosure reports, reporting by national political party committees, electronic disclosure, public access to broadcasting records, and software for filing reports. It also addresses limits on soft money and contribution limits. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require additional monthly reports from Principal Campaign Committees, to be filed by the 20th day after the last day of the month, except for November and December. A year-end report must be filed by January 31 of the following year. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require quarterly reports from Principal Campaign Committees, to be filed by the 15th day after the last day of each calendar quarter. The report for the quarter ending December 31 must be complete as of that date. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 now requires quarterly reports from Principal Campaign Committees, due by the 15th day after the end of each quarter. The report for the quarter ending December 31 must be filed by January 31 of the following year. Additionally, a national committee of a political party must file the reports required under subparagraph (B). The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is being amended to change quarterly reports to monthly reports for certain sections. Amendment to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 changes quarterly reports to monthly reports for specific sections. SEC. 102. REPORTING BY NATIONAL POLITICAL PARTY COMMITTEES. Section 304 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require national and congressional political committees to report all receipts and disbursements during the reporting period, with itemization for amounts exceeding $200 from any person in a calendar year. The political committee must separately itemize reporting for any person who contributes over $200 in a calendar year, following the same reporting periods as required for political committees under subsection (a). SEC. 103. INCREASED ELECTRONIC DISCLOSURE. The Commission will make reports available online and at their offices within 24 hours of receiving the information. SEC. 104. PUBLIC ACCESS TO BROADCASTING RECORDS. Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to require licensees to maintain and make available for public inspection a complete record of requests to purchase broadcast time related to political matters of national importance. Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 now requires licensees to keep a record of requests to purchase broadcast time for political matters of national importance, including information on acceptance/rejection and rates charged. Licensees must keep records of requests to purchase broadcast time for political matters, including acceptance/rejection, rates charged, air date/time, class of time purchased, and candidate/issue information. Licensees must keep records of requests to purchase broadcast time for political matters, including candidate/issue information, name of candidate, authorized committee, treasurer, and contact information for the person purchasing the time. Licensees are required to maintain records of requests to purchase broadcast time for political matters, including candidate/issue information, contact details of the person purchasing the time, and a list of key executives or board members. This information must be placed in a political file promptly and retained for a minimum of 2 years. SEC. 105. SOFTWARE FOR FILING OF REPORTS. Section 304(a) of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include the development and provision of software for filing reports at no cost to individuals required to file under the Act. Any person required to file a designation, statement, or report under the Act must use software developed for such purpose. SEC. 201 imposes limits on soft money of national political party committees under Title III of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. SEC. 201 imposes limits on donations to national political party committees, restricting individuals from donating over $60,000 in a calendar year. The text chunk outlines restrictions on donations to national political party committees, capping individual disbursements at $60,000 per calendar year and indexing the amount based on price increases after 2001. SEC. 202. JUDICIAL REVIEW. Expedited Review: Members of Congress, candidates, national party committees, or affected individuals can challenge the constitutionality of section 324 of the Federal Election Campaign Act in the US District Court for the District of Columbia. Appeals from this court can go directly to the Supreme Court. The District Court for the District of Columbia and the Supreme Court of the United States have the duty to expedite the disposition of any matter brought under subsection (a) of the Federal Election Campaign Act. Appeals from the District Court's decision can be directly made to the Supreme Court within specific time frames. States to expedite the disposition of matters under subsection (a) of the Federal Election Campaign Act. Enforcement of section 324 of the Act is stayed until final disposition by the Supreme Court. This section applies only in specific circumstances. The Supreme Court of the United States will review actions filed under this section within 30 days of the Act's effective date. SEC. 203. INCREASE IN CONTRIBUTION LIMITS. Increase in contribution limits under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971: Individual and Political Committee limits raised to $3,000, $60,000, and $15,000 respectively. Additionally, the limit for paragraph 3 is increased to $75,000 with the removal of the second sentence. In paragraph (3), the contribution limit is increased to $75,000 and the second sentence is removed. Additionally, the multicandidate limits are raised to $7,500 and $30,000. In subparagraph (D), contribution limits are increased to $30,000 for subparagraph (B) and $7,500 for subparagraph (C). A new limit of $15,000 is set for national committee contributions to candidates and their authorized committees. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits for elections exceeding $15,000. Indexing under section 315(c) is modified to adjust limitations annually after 2002 based on percentage differences. After 2002, limitations on contributions for elections exceeding $15,000 will be increased annually based on percentage differences. The increased amounts will remain in effect for the calendar year, with a 2-year period for limitations under subsections (a) and (h). The contribution limits for Senate candidates from national party committees and senatorial campaign committees are increased from $17,500 to $60,000. Effective dates for these changes are specified. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits for Senate candidates from national party committees and senatorial campaign committees from $17,500 to $60,000. The amendments will apply to calendar years beginning after December 31, 2001, with some exceptions for amendments made by subsection (c) which will apply to calendar years after December 31, 2002. SEC. 301 prohibits the solicitation of political party soft money in federal buildings. The amendment to Section 607 of title 18, United States Code, removes a reference to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 and defines "contribution" as a gift or money given in connection with elections for Federal office or political committees. The amendment to Title 18 prohibits donations to elections for Federal office, political committees, or party committees. SEC. 302. UPDATE OF PENALTY AMOUNTS. Section 309 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to adjust dollar amounts for inflation after 2001 based on the price index. This adjustment does not apply to amounts under subsection (d) other than the $25,000 amount. SEC. 303. Filing of Senate reports with the Federal Election Commission. Section 302 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to specify that all required filings shall be submitted to the Commission. Conforming amendments are made to Title III of the Act regarding the submission of designations, statements, and reports. Amendments are made to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to specify that all required filings shall be submitted to the Commission. Conforming amendments are made to Title III of the Act regarding the submission of designations, statements, and reports. Additionally, changes are made to references of the "Secretary" to "Commission and Secretary of State" in certain sections.
